((ul))((hl))Thought is produced((/hl))((/ul))((ul)) in me ((/ul))((ul))((hl))as uncoordinated flashes((/hl))((/ul))((ul)), withdrawing endlessly from a term to which its movement pushes it((/ul)). I can't tell if I'm expressing human helplessness this way, or my own . . . I don't know, though I'm not hopeful of even some outwardly satisfying outcome. Isn't there an advantage in creating philosophy as I do? A flash in the night--a language belonging to a brief moment . . . Perhaps in this respect this latest moment contains a simple truth. ((ul))((hl))In order to will knowledge((/hl))((/ul))((ul)), by an indirect expedient ((/ul))((ul))((hl))I tend to become the whole universe((/hl))((/ul))((ul)). But ((/ul))((ul))((hl))in this movement I can't be a whole human being((/hl))((/ul))((ul)), since I submit to a particular goal, becoming the whole. Granted, if I could become it, I would thus be a whole human being. But in my effort, don't I distance myself from exactly that? And ((/ul))((ul))((hl))how can I become the whole without becoming a whole human being? ((/hl))((/ul))((ul))((hl))I can't be this whole human being except when I let go((/hl))((/ul))((ul)). I can't be this through willpower: my will necessarily has to will outcomes! But if misfortune (or chance) wills me to let go, then I know I am an integral, whole humanness, subordinate to nothing((/ul)). In other words, ((ul))the moment of revolt inherent in willing a knowledge beyond practical ends can't be indefinitely continued. And ((/ul))((ul))((hl))in order to be the whole universe, humankind has to let go and abandon its principle((/hl))((/ul))((ul)), accepting as the sole criterion of what it is the tendency to go beyond what it is((/ul)). This existence that I am is a revolt against existence and is indefinite desire. For this existence God was simply a stage and now here he is, looming large, grown from unfathomable experience, comically perched on the stake used for impalement. ((ul))((hl))My method has confusion as a consequence((/hl))((/ul))((ul))--and in the long run ((/ul))((ul))((hl))this confusion is unbearable((/hl))((/ul)) (particularly for me!). This is something to be corrected if possible . . . But for now, I want to elucidate the meaning of the above words. For me ((ul))((hl))nothingness is a limit of an individual existence. Beyond its defined limits((/hl))((/ul))((ul))--in time and in space--((/ul))((ul))((hl))this existence or being no longer exists((/hl))((/ul))((ul)), no longer is. For us, ((/ul))((ul))((hl))that nonbeing is filled with meaning: ((/hl))((/ul))((ul))((hl))I know I can be reduced to nothing((/hl))((/ul))((ul))((hl)). Limited being is only a particular being((/hl))((/ul))((ul)). Although, does there exist such a thing as the totality of being (understood as the sum of beings)?((/ul))

tag:
I abandon myself to peace, to the point of annihilation.
The noises of struggle are lost in death, as rivers are lost in the sea, as stars
burst in the night.
The strength of combat is fulfilled in the silence of all action.
I enter into peace as I enter into a dark unknown.
I fall in this dark unknown.
I myself become this dark unknown.
cite: [Georges Bataille, Erotism: Death and Sensuality, 1957]
text: Bataille 37 (Georges Bataille, crazy librarian, “The Practice of Joy Before Death,” in “Visions of Excess: Selected Writings 1927-1939,” translated by Alan Stoekl ///ghs-sc)
***edited for gendered and ableist language; we do not endorse it

((ul))When a((/ul)) man ((ul))[person] finds((/ul)) him((ul))[them]self situated in such a way that the world is happily reflected in((/ul)) him((ul))[them], without entailing any destruction or suffering((/ul))—as on a beautiful spring morning—he ((ul))[they] can let((/ul)) him((ul))[them]self be carried away by the resulting enchantment or simple joy((/ul)). But he((ul))[they] can also perceive((/ul)), at the same time, ((ul))the weight and the vain yearning for empty rest implied by this beatitude((/ul)). At that moment, ((ul))((hl))something cruelly rises up((/hl))((/ul)) in him that is comparable to a bird of prey that tears open the throat of a smaller bird in an apparently peaceful and clear blue sky. He ((ul))((hl))[they] recognize((/hl))((/ul))s ((ul))((hl))that((/hl))((/ul)) he ((ul))((hl))[they] cannot fulfill((/hl))((/ul)) his ((ul))((hl))[their] life without surrendering to an inexorable movement((/hl))((/ul)), whose violence he can feel acting on the most remote areas of his being with a rigor that frightens him. If he turns to other beings who do not go beyond beatitude, he experiences no hate, but, on the contrary, he sympathizes with necessary pleasures; he clashes only with those who pretend to attain fulfillment in their lives, who act out a risk-free charade in order to be recognized as having attained fulfillment, while in fact they only speak of fulfillment. But he should not succumb to vertigo. For ((ul))((hl))vertigo((/hl))((/ul))((ul)) swiftly exhausts and ((/ul))((ul))((hl))threatens to revive a concern for happy leisure((/hl))((/ul))((ul)) or, if that cannot be attained, ((/ul))((ul))((hl))for a painless emptiness((/hl))((/ul)). Or ((ul))((hl))if((/hl))((/ul)) he ((ul))((hl))[they] do((/hl))((/ul))es ((ul))((hl))not give in, and if((/hl))((/ul))((ul)) ((/ul))he ((ul))((hl))[they] tear((/hl))((/ul))((ul)) ((/ul))him((ul))((hl))[them]self((/hl))((/ul))((ul)) completely ((/ul))((ul))((hl))apart((/hl))((/ul))((ul)) in terrified haste,((/ul)) he ((ul))((hl))[they] enter((/hl))((/ul))s ((ul))((hl))death in such a way that nothing is more horrible((/hl))((/ul)). He alone is happy who, having experienced vertigo to the point of trembling in his bones, to the point of being incapable of measuring the extent of his fall, suddenly finds the unhoped-for strength to turn his agony into a joy capable of freezing and transfiguring those who meet it. But the only ambition that can take hold of a man who, in cold blood, sees his life fulfilled in rending agony, cannot aspire to a grandeur that only extreme chance has at its disposal. This kind of violent decision, which disrupts his repose, does not necessarily entail either his vertigo or his fall in sudden death. In him, this decision may become an act and a power by which he devotes himself to the rigor whose movement ceaselessly closes in on him, as cutting as the beak of a bird of prey. Contemplation is only the context, sometimes calm and sometimes stormy, in which the rapid force of his action must one day be put to the test. ((ul))((hl))The mystical existence of((/hl))((/ul))((ul)) the one whose ((/ul))((ul))((hl))"joy before death" has become inner violence((/hl))((/ul))((ul)) can never attain the satisfying beatitude of the Christian who gives himself a foretaste of eternity. ((/ul))((ul))((hl))The mystic of "joy before death" can never be seen as cornered, for((/hl))((/ul)) he is ((ul))((hl))[they are] able to laugh((/hl))((/ul))((ul)) complacently ((/ul))((ul))((hl))at every human endeavor and to know every accessible enthusiasm((/hl))((/ul))((ul)): but ((/ul))((ul))((hl))the totality of life((/hl))((/ul))((ul))—ecstatic contemplation and lucid knowledge accomplished in a single action that cannot fail to become risk—((/ul))((ul))((hl))is((/hl))((/ul))((ul)), however, ((/ul))((ul))((hl))just as inexorably((/hl))((/ul)) his ((ul))((hl))[their] lot as death is that of the condemned((/hl))((/ul)) man((ul))((hl))[person]((/hl))((/ul)). The texts that follow cannot alone constitute an initiation into the exercise of a mysticism of "joy before death." While admitting that a method of initiation might exist, they do not represent even a part of it. ((ul))Since ((/ul))((ul))((hl))oral initiation is((/hl))((/ul))((ul)) itself ((/ul))((ul))((hl))difficult, it is ((/hl))((/ul))((ul))((hl))impossible((/hl))((/ul))((ul))((hl)) to give((/hl))((/ul))((ul)) in a few pages ((/ul))((ul))((hl))more than the vaguest representation((/hl))((/ul))((ul)) of that which by nature cannot be grasped((/ul)). On the whole, these writings represent, moreover, less exercises strictly speaking than simple descriptions of a contemplative state or of an ecstatic contemplation. These descriptions would not even be acceptable if they were not given for what they are, in other words, as free. Only the very first text could be proposed as an exercise. While it is appropriate to use the word mysticism when speaking of "joy before death" and its practice, this implies no more than an affective resemblance between this practice and those of the religions of Asia or Europe. There is no reason to link any presuppositions concerning an alleged deeper reality with a joy that has no object other than immediate life. ((ul))((hl))"Joy before death" belongs only to the person for whom there is no beyond((/hl))((/ul))((ul))((hl)); it is the only intellectually honest route in the search for ecstasy((/hl))((/ul)). Besides, ((ul))how could a beyond, a God or what resembles God, still be acceptable?((/ul)) No words are clear enough to express the happy disdain of the one who "dances with the time that kills him" for those who take refuge in the expectation of eternal beatitude. This kind of fretful saintliness—which first had to he sheltered from erotic excess—has now lost all its power: one can only laugh at a sacred drunkenness allied with a horror of debauchery. Prudery may be healthy for backward souls, but those who would be afraid of nude girls or whisky would have little to do with "joy before death." Only a shameless, indecent saintliness can lead to a sufficiently happy loss of self. ((ul))((hl))"Joy before death" means that life can be glorified from root to summit. It robs of meaning everything that is an intellectual or moral beyond((/hl))((/ul))((ul)), substance, God, immutable order, ((/ul))((ul))((hl))or salvation((/hl))((/ul))((ul))((hl)). It is an apotheosis of that which is perishable, apotheosis of flesh((/hl))((/ul))((ul)) and alcohol as well as of the trances of mysticism.((/ul)) The religious forms it rediscovers are the naive forms that antedate the intrusion of a servile morality: ((ul))((hl))it renews the((/hl))((/ul))((ul)) kind of ((/ul))((ul))((hl))tragic jubilation that man "is" as soon as he stops behaving [weakly]((/hl))((/ul))like a cripple, ((ul))((hl))glorifying((/hl))((/ul))((ul)) necessary ((/ul))((ul))((hl))work and letting himself be emasculated by the fear of tomorrow.((/hl))((/ul))((ul)) ((/ul))

tag: Death is the most luxurious form of life. It is death and death alone that ensures the renewal of life.
cite: Bataille 97 (Georges Bataille, crazy librarian, “Death,” from “The Bataille Reader,” translated by Michelle and Stuart Kendall, 1997 ///ghs-sc)
text: ((ul))((hl))Death Is((/hl))((/ul))((ul)) Finally ((/ul))((ul))((hl))the Most Luxurious Form of Life((/hl))((/ul)) What is disconcerting about these movements where opposed forms are interdependent is due to the common misappreciation of death. It calls for us to despise the link associating death with erotIcIsm, regarded as a promise of life. ((ul))((hl))It is easy, but((/hl))((/ul))((ul)), all in all, it is ((/ul))((ul))((hl))dishonourable((/hl))((/ul))((ul)) (a lack of intellectual virility) to ((/ul))((ul))((hl))turn away from the luxurious truth of death((/hl))((/ul))((ul)): there is no doubt that ((/ul))((ul))((hl))death is the youth of the world((/hl))((/ul))((ul)). We don't admit this, we don't want to admit it, for a rather sad reason: we are perhaps young at heart, but ((/ul))((ul))this doesn't mean we are more alert((/ul))((ul)). Otherwise, how could we not be aware that ((/ul))((ul))((hl))death, and death alone, constantly ensures the renewal of life((/hl))((/ul))?≥ The worst is that, in a sense, we know this very well, but we are just as quick to forget it. The law given in nature is so simple as to defy ignorance. According to this law, ((ul))((hl))life is effusion((/hl))((/ul))((ul)); it is contrary to equilibrium, to stability. It is the tumultuous movement that bursts forth and consumes itself. ((/ul))((ul))((hl))Its perpetual explosion is possible on one condition: ((/hl))((/ul))((ul))((hl))that the spent organisms give way to new ones((/hl))((/ul))((ul)), which enter the dance with new forces.((/ul))2 We could really not imagine a more costly process. Life is possible at much less expense: compared to that of an infusorian, the individual organism of a mammal, especially a carnivore, is an abyss where enormous quantities of energy are swallowed up, are destroyed. ((ul))((hl))The growth of plants presupposes the amassing of decayed substances((/hl))((/ul))((ul)). Plant-eaters consume tons of living (plant) substance before a small amount of meat allows a carnivore its great releases, its great nervous expenditures((/ul)). It even appears that the more costly the life-generating processes are, the more squander the production of organisms has required, the more satisfactory the operation is. ((ul))The principle of producing at the least expense is not so much a human idea as a narrowly capitalist one((/ul)) (it makes sense only from the viewpoint of the incorporated company). ((ul))((hl))The movement of human life((/hl))((/ul))((ul)) even ((/ul))((ul))((hl))tends toward anguish, as the sign of expenditures that are finally excessive((/hl))((/ul))((ul)), that go beyond what we can bear. ((/ul))((ul))((hl))Everything within us demands that death lay waste to us((/hl))((/ul))((ul)): we anticipate these multiple trials, these new beginnings, unproductive from the standpoint of reason, this wholesale destruction of effective force accomplished in the transfer of one individual's life to other, younger, individuals((/ul)). Deep down, we even assent to the condition that results, that is almost intolerable, in this condition of individuals destined for suffering and inevitable annihilation. Or rather, ((ul))((hl))were it not for this intolerable condition((/hl))((/ul))((ul)), so harsh that the will constantly wavers, ((/ul))((ul))((hl))we would not be satisfied((/hl))((/ul)). (How significant at present that a book3 is entitled, ludicrously, Afin que nul ne meure!...) Today our judgements are formed in disappointing circumstances: ((ul))those among us who best make themselves heard are unaware (and want at all cost to be unaware) that ((/ul))((ul))((hl))life is the luxury of which death is the highest degree((/hl))((/ul))((ul)), that of all the luxuries of life, human life is the most extravagantly expensive, that, finally, ((/ul))((ul))((hl))an increased apprehension of death((/hl))((/ul))((ul)), when life's security wears thin, ((/ul))((ul))((hl))is at the highest level of ruinous refinement((/hl))((/ul)) ... But oblivious of this, ((ul))((hl))they only add to the anguish((/hl))((/ul))((ul)) without which a life devoted entirely to luxury would be less boldly luxurious((/ul)). For if it is human to be luxurious, what to say of a luxury of which anguish is the product and which anguish does not moderate?

tag: The aff relies on the temporality of anticipation, entrapped within notions of futurity and utility that reduce our lives to nothing but a tool. This form of phallicized whiteness attempts to endlessly project us into the future, grounding itself in the denial of death. Only through an acceptance of our demise can we escape the order of instrumental reason and live sovereignly.
cite: Winnubst 06 (Shannon Winnubst is a professor of women’s, gender, and sexuality studies at Ohio State University, “Queering Freedom,” 2006 ///ghs-sc)
text: ***edited for gendered language

For Bataille, ((ul))((hl))the servility to utility is displayed((/hl))((/ul))((ul)) particularly in the temporality of such a world—((/ul))((ul))((hl))the temporality of anticipation((/hl))((/ul)). Returning again to the role of the tool, he writes, ((ul))In efficacious activity((/ul)) man ((ul))((hl))[a person] becomes ((/hl))((/ul))((ul))((hl))the equivalent of a tool((/hl))((/ul))((ul)), which produces; ((/ul))he is ((ul))[they are] like the thing the tool is, being itself a product((/ul)). The implication of these facts is quite clear: ((ul))the tool’s meaning is given by the future((/ul)), in what the tool will produce, in the future utilization of the product: like the tool, he who serves—who works—has the value of that which will be later, not of that which is. (1988–91, 2:218) ((ul))((hl))The reduction of our lives to the order of utility forces us to project ourselves endlessly into the future((/hl))((/ul)). Bataille writes of this as our anguished state, caused by this anticipation “that must be called anticipation of oneself. For he must apprehend himself in the future, through the anticipated results of his action” (1988–91, 2:218). ((ul))This is why advanced capitalism and ((/ul))((ul))((hl))phallicized whiteness must ground themselves in a denial of death: death precludes the arrival of this future((/hl))((/ul))((ul)). It cuts us off from ourselves, severing us from the future self that is always our real and true self.((/ul)) Resisting the existential turn, however, Bataille refuses to read this denial of death as an ontological condition of humanity. For Bataille, ((ul))((hl))this is a historical((/hl))((/ul))((ul)) and economic ((/ul))((ul))((hl))denial, ((/hl))((/ul))((ul))((hl))one in which only a culture grounded in the anticipation of the future must participate((/hl))((/ul))((ul)). He frames it primarily as a problem of the intellect. In the reduction of the world to the order of utility, ((/ul))((ul))((hl))we have reduced our lives((/hl))((/ul))((ul)) and experiences ((/ul))((ul))((hl))to the order of instrumental reason((/hl))((/ul)). This order necessarily operates in a sequential temporality, facing forward toward the time when the results will be achieved, the questions solved, the theorems proved—and also when political domination will be ended and ethical an- guish quieted. As Bataille credits Hegel for seeing, “knowledge is never given to us except by unfolding in time” (1988–91, 2:202). It never appears to us except, finally, “as the result of a calculated effort, an operation useful to some end” (1988–91, 2:202)—and its utility, as we have seen, only drives it forward toward some future utility, endlessly. There are always new and future objects of thought to conquer and domesticate. Within this order of reason, death presents the cessation of the very practice of knowledge itself.((ul)) Severing us from the future objects of thought and from our future selves, ((/ul))((ul))((hl))“death prevents man from attaining himself”((/hl))((/ul)) (1988–91, 2:218). As Bataille explains, “the fear of death appears linked from the start to the projection of oneself into a future time, which [is] an effect of the positing of oneself as a thing” (1988–91, 2:218). ((ul))The ((/ul))((ul))((hl))fear of death derives from ((/hl))((/ul))((ul))((hl))the subordination to the order of utility and((/hl))((/ul))((ul)) its dominant form of the intellect, ((/ul))((ul))((hl))instrumental reason((/hl))((/ul))((ul)).((/ul)) While death is unarguably a part of the human condition, for Bataille ((ul))the ((/ul))((ul))((hl))fear of death((/hl))((/ul))((ul)) is a historically habituated response, one that ((/ul))((ul))((hl))grounds cultures of((/hl))((/ul))((ul)) advanced capitalism and ((/ul))((ul))((hl))phallicized whiteness((/hl))((/ul)). In those frames of late modernity, ((ul))((hl))death introduces an ontological scarcity into the very human condition: it represents((/hl))((/ul))((ul)) finitude, ((/ul))((ul))((hl))the ultimate limit((/hl))((/ul))((ul))((hl)). We must distance ourselves from such threats, and we do so((/hl))((/ul))((ul)) most often ((/ul))((ul))((hl))by ((/hl))((/ul))((ul))((hl))projecting them onto sexualized, racialized, and classed bodies((/hl))((/ul)). But for Bataille, ((ul))se((/ul))((ul))rvility to the order of knowledge is as unnecessary as servility to the order of utility. To die humanly, he argues, is to accept “the subordination of the thing”((/ul)) (1988– 91, 2:219), which places us in the schema that separates our present self from the future, desired, anticipated self: “to die humanly is to have of the future being, of the one who matters most in our eyes, the senseless idea that he is not” (1988–91, 2:219). But if we are not trapped in the endless anticipation of our future self as the index of meaning in our lives, we may not be anguished by this cessation: “((ul))((hl))If we live sovereignly, the ((/hl))((/ul))((ul))((hl))representation of death is impossible((/hl))((/ul))((ul)), for the present is not subject to the demands of the future((/ul))” (1988–91, 2:219). ((ul))((hl))To live sovereignly is not to escape death,((/hl))((/ul))((ul)) which is ontologically impossible. ((/ul))((ul))((hl))But((/hl))((/ul))((ul)) it is ((/ul))((ul))((hl))to refuse the fear((/hl))((/ul))((ul)), and subsequent attempts at disavowal, ((/ul))((ul))((hl))of death((/hl))((/ul)) as the ontological condition that defines humanity. Rather than trying to transgress this ultimate limit and prohibition, ((ul))the sovereign((/ul)) man ((ul))[person] “cannot die fleeing((/ul)). He ((ul))[they] cannot let the threat of death deliver((/ul)) him ((ul))[them] over to the horror of a desperate yet impossible flight”((/ul)) (1988–91, 2:219). ((ul))((hl))Living in a temporal mode in which ((/hl))((/ul))((ul))((hl))“anticipation would dissolve into NOTHING”((/hl))((/ul)) (1988–91, 2: 208), ((ul))the sovereign((/ul)) man ((ul))[person] “lives and dies like an animal”((/ul)) (1988–91, 2:219). He lives and dies ((ul))((hl))[they live and die] ((/hl))((/ul))((ul))((hl))without the anxiety((/hl))((/ul))((ul))((hl)) invoked by the forever unknown and forever encroaching anticipation of the future((/hl))((/ul)). As Bataille encourages us elsewhere, “Think of the voracity of animals, as against the composure of a cook” (1988–91, 2:83).

tag: The order of instrumental reason provides the justification for violence – their focus on utility reifies all forms of discrimination
cite: Winnubst 06 (Shannon Winnubst is a professor of women’s, gender, and sexuality studies at Ohio State University, “Queering Freedom,” 2006 ///ghs-sc)
text: *edited for ableist language; we don’t endorse it

This is the domination and violence of our historical present, late modernity: to reduce our lives so completely to the order of instrumental reason that we cannot conceive of any political or philosophical problem without reducing it to that narrow conception of reason. This renders us captive to presuppositions which assume that solutions to problems must follow the same temporal register as the posing of the problem itself— i.e., that they must appear immediately effective and useful if we are to recognize them as solutions at all. But what if these are only truncated, shortsighted views? ((ul))What if ((/ul))((ul))((hl))a vital resistance to politics of domination comes through freeing ourselves from these((/hl))((/ul))((ul)) closed ((/ul))((ul))((hl))economies of late modernity and their ((/hl))((/ul))((ul))clearly demarcated, ((/ul))((ul))((hl))controlled((/hl))((/ul))((ul)), mastered, ((/ul))((ul))((hl))and useful ends((/hl))((/ul))((ul))?((/ul)) What if a vital resistance to politics of domination requires a temporal register other than that of immediate and clear efficacy? As Bataille tells us sympathetically, “It is not easy to realize one’s own ends if one must, in trying to do so, carry out a movement that surpasses them” (1988– 91, 1:21). His orientation toward general economies asks us to think differently from the habituated patterns of our historical present. In his language, this historical present is “characterized by the fact that judgments concerning the general situation proceed from a particular point of view” (1988– 91, 1:39). This particularity can be outlined, described, pinned down, and its blind spots excavated: I attempt to do so in this text. But to think generally from and about the historical present may lead us into different questions and different orientations: it has led me to query systems of domination through the registers of temporality and spatiality, while framing them through the identity categories (race, gender, sexuality, class, religion) that are their most explicit historical tools. ((ul))For example, how does ((/ul))((ul))((hl))the temporality of a persistent future orientation ground systems of racism, sexism, and heterosexism((/hl))((/ul))((ul))? What assumptions about the ontology of space allow for the biological conception of race that groundsracism, or of sex that grounds sexism and heterosexism? Bataille warns us that, ((/ul))((ul))((hl))if we do not learn to think in this counter-cultural register((/hl))((/ul))((ul)) of general economy((/ul))((ul)), ((/ul))((ul))((hl))we will always be subordinated to((/hl))((/ul))((ul)) the ((/ul))((ul))((hl))violent and((/hl))((/ul))((ul)) even ((/ul))((ul))((hl))catastrophic expressions((/hl))((/ul))((ul)) of the excess, abundant energy of the planet, ((/ul))((ul))((hl))such as war and imperialist domination.((/hl))((/ul))((ul)) ((/ul))We do have a choice in this matter. But that choice is not one which will derive from calculating our interest, analyzing the specific problem, or charting the solution: it will not derive from the domains of instrumental reason and its persistent mandate of utility. It may, rather, involve recuperating senses of freedom lost to us in late modernity, where nation-states promise freedom as the facile liberation from subservience and mastery as the domination of nature and culture. To think generally may lead toward sensing freedom as “a dangerous breaking loose...a will to assume those risks without which there is no freedom” (1988– 91, 1:38). It is toward recuperating these more general senses of freedom, which Bataille signifies as “sovereign” and I signify as “queer” in this historical period of late modernity and phallicized whiteness, that this text moves.

tag: The lines of hell never stop expanding – the nuclear bomb is indistinguishable from humanity, existing at the sacred core of humanity’s origins. The death by fire they articulate is necessarily unremarkable.
cite: Sivak 15 (Andrew Mark Sivak, Ph.D., is a professor of History of Consciousness UC Santa Cruz, “Destroyer of Worlds: War and Apocalypse in the Nuclear Epoch,” 2015 ///ghs-sc)
text: ((ul))The philosophical counter-argument to the theory of Hiroshima as event articulated by Anders was established years prior to this flare up with Jaspers by Georges Bataille,((/ul)) in his critical review of John Hersey's Hiroshima, which opened with a 162 Anders, “Theses,” 494-5. 142 provocative formulation of infernal recurrence. “((ul))Let's admit it((/ul)),” he admonished, “((ul))((hl))the population of hell increases annually by fifty million((/hl))((/ul))((ul))s souls . . . ((/ul))((ul))((hl))A world war((/hl))((/ul))((ul)) may accelerate the rhythm slightly, but it ((/ul))((ul))((hl))cannot significantly alter it((/hl))((/ul))((ul)). To the ten million killed in the war from 1914 to 1918 one must add the two hundred million who, during the same period, were fated to die natural deaths.163 ((/ul))((ul))((hl))Hell did not stop expanding((/hl))((/ul))((ul)) after Hiroshima((/ul)). Furthermore, there was for Bataille nothing particularly noteworthy about the ways in which the victims at Hiroshima suffered: If the misfortunes of Hiroshima are faced up to freely from the perspective of a sensibility that is not faked, they cannot be isolated from other misfortunes. ((ul))The tens of thousands of victims of the atom bomb are on the same level as the tens of millions whom nature yearly hands over to death. One cannot deny the differences in age and suffering, but origin and intensity change nothing: ((/ul))((ul))((hl))horror is everywhere the same((/hl))((/ul))((ul)).((/ul)) The point that, in principle, the one horror is preventable while the other is not is, in the last analysis, a matter of indifference.164 163 Bataille, “Concerning the Accounts,” 221. 164 Ibid, 228. Emphasis added. However, ((ul))the human meaning of Hiroshima's burning((/ul)), as distinct from the animality of bodily suffering and death, ((ul))was important to Bataille, who in this passage distances himself from the contextualizing moves represented by Churchill and the dehumanizing descriptors used by Truman and Life: “But the death of sixty thousand is charged with meaning, in that it depended on their fellow men to kill them or let them live. ((/ul))((ul))((hl))The atom bomb draws its meaning from its ((/hl))((/ul))((ul))((hl))human origin((/hl))((/ul))((ul))((hl)): it is the possibility that the hands of man deliberately hang suspended over the future((/hl))((/ul))((ul)). And it is a means of action: the fear produced by a tidal wave or a volcano has no meaning((/ul)), whereas uranium fission a project whose goal is to impose, by fear, the will of the one who provokes it. At the same time it puts an end to the projects of those whom it strikes. It is by representing possible projects, which in turn are intended to make other projects impossible, that an atom bomb 143 The horrific carnage and mass death had precedent. ((ul))Arguing for the exceptionality of Hiroshima was((/ul)), according to Bataille, a cheap form of sentimentality and in the end, ((ul))dishonest. The cruelties of the Second World War did nothing to alter the underlying situation of death: the ((/ul))((ul))((hl))lines at the gates of Hell are only getting longer.((/hl))((/ul))((ul))((hl)) Death by fire((/hl))((/ul)), in whatever form, ((ul))((hl))was((/hl))((/ul))((ul)) in Bataille’s eyes ((/ul))((ul))((hl))unremarkable((/hl))((/ul)), for “each fire is all fires.” ((ul))What so moved Bataille about atomic bombs and the idea of nuclear war((/ul)), contra Anders, ((ul))was not escalating thresholds of death((/ul)) (individual, collective, the end of a world shaped by humanity) and he disdained moralistic critiques, especially those based on a concern for the suffering of others. For Bataille, ((ul))what ((/ul))((ul))((hl))the nuclear bomb revealed((/hl))((/ul))((ul)) was ((/ul))((ul))((hl))the ((/hl))((/ul))((ul))((hl))dark truth((/hl))((/ul))((ul))((hl)) of human destiny((/hl))((/ul))((ul))—not what we have since become due to a twist of fate but ((/ul))((ul))((hl))what we were from the very start((/hl))((/ul))((ul)), though we could not see it.((/ul)) Over a decade after his review of Hiroshima, revising his earlier interpretation of Hiroshima's bombing being more of the same, he wrote in another article titled, “Unlivable Earth,” that We know that we cannot attain this world without denying, without suppressing what we are. But in catching sight of it, we are led to forget its real takes on a human meaning. Otherwise, it would merely have the animal meaning of smoking out termites.” Ibid, 226-7. 144 spirit, its horrible tribal wars, its tortures, its massacres; or, in a less primitive civilization, the reduction of an unfortunate group of conquered men to slavery, men transported by force, under the lash, toward unspeakable markets. Only by dint of grievous lies can we conceal the accursed truth of history. ((ul))((hl))There is something frightful in human destiny((/hl))((/ul))((ul)), which undoubtedly was always at the limit of this unlimited nightmare that the most modern weaponry, the nuclear bomb, finally announces((/ul)).165 And later in the same piece: The first men, as well as some very primitive savages today, think they are really animals: because animals are, in their mind, the most holy, having a sacred quality, which men have lost. Thus, according to the simplest among us, animals, not men, are gods: animals alone have retained these supernatural qualities, which men have lost. Of course it is hard for us to think that we are becoming completely wretched! And yet . . . ((ul))we might have a sublime idea of the animal now that we have ceased being certain that one day the nuclear bomb will not make the planet an unlivable place for man.166 ((/ul))((ul))((hl))The deep truth of nuclear war is that it announces the revelation of our ((/hl))((/ul))((ul))((hl))lost animality((/hl))((/ul)). By contextualizing the atomic bomb in this way, Bataille was not (in the vein of someone like Churchill) attempting to diminish the significance of atomic bombs. To the contrary, driven by “the will to create a force, starting from an awareness of the misery and the grandeur of this perishable existence that has befallen us,” Bataille once 165 Bataille, Cradle of Humanity, 176. 166 Ibid, 178. 145 proclaimed: “((ul))STANDING AND FACING DESTINY remains in my eyes the essential aspect of knowledge.”((/ul))167 For him, ((ul))the nuclear bomb did not reveal a new situation((/ul)), as Anders believed, ((ul))so much as it represented the real of an old situation that seemed preoccupied with continuity but was suicidal from the start((/ul)). According ((ul))to Bataille, ((/ul))((ul))((hl))the nuclear epoch did not threaten humanity so much as ((/hl))((/ul))((ul))((hl))it was indistinguishable from humanity((/hl))((/ul))((ul))((hl)). Nuclear war would constitute an infernal return of an animal indifference to death—((/hl))((/ul))((ul))((hl))the sacred core of humanity's origins((/hl))((/ul))((ul)).((/ul))

tag: Our act of transgressive eroticism allows for the rawest form of communication – the act of violent unproductivity create continuous acts of shared inner experience
cite: Botting and Wilson 97 (Fred Botting and Scott Wilson, “The Bataille Reader”, 1997 ///ghs-sc)
text: For Bataille, ((ul))((hl))it is((/hl))((/ul))((ul)) 'the identity of((/ul)) these ((ul))perfect contraries, ((/ul))((ul))((hl))divine ecstasy and((/hl))((/ul))((ul)) its opposite, ((/ul))((ul))((hl))extreme horror' that blows identity apart((/hl))((/ul))((ul)), unleashes experience from the 'prison' of anguish ((/ul))((ul))((hl))and establishes continuity with alterity: communication((/hl))((/ul)). This statement comes as the 'inevitable conclusion to a history of eroticism'. It is with eroticism that 'the contraries seem visibly conjoined, where the religious horror disclosed in sacrifice becomes linked to the abyss of eroticism'. 21 Two texts written in 1941 exemplify the link between horror and eroticism. 'The torment' from Inner Experience, already cited, is the companion to another text written in a different register, though one concerned, essentially, with the same experience. 'I wrote this slim volume in September and October 1941, just before 'Le Supplice' ['The torment'], which makes up the second part of L'Experience interieure. To my mind the two texts are closely interdependent and one cannot be understood without the other . . . I could not have written 'Le Supplice' if I had not first provided its lewd key.'22 Madame Edwarda has been called by Maurice Blanchot, one of the first persons to read it during the worst days of the Occupation in 1941/3 'the most beautiful narrative of our time'.24 ((ul))This narrative, like 'The torment', makes the atheological connection between inner experience and eroticism in a horrifyingly literal way((/ul)):¶ She was seated, she held one long leg stuck up in the air, to open her crack yet wider she used her fingers to draw the folds of skin apart ... 'Why', I stammered in a subdued tone, 'why are you doing that?' 'You can see for yourself ', she said, 'I'm GOD'. (p. 229)¶ ((ul))As an account of a visit to a brothel, the story is quite banal. The intensity of the experience, however, invests the encounter with the mystico-philosophical significance of 'eroticism'((/ul)), reversing the veiled pornographic flickerings of erotica. The difference Bataille suggests, in his Preface on the intentions of 'Pierre Angelique', pseudonymous author of MadameEdwarda, lies in the unusual 'gravity' with which the matter of sexual life is treated, as opposed to the customary 'making light' of it (p. 223). ((ul))((hl))In eroticism the object of desire radiates with a nocturnal brilliance((/hl))((/ul))((ul)) that reduces the subject to nothing but the infinite movement of desire itself. ((/ul))((ul))((hl))In the ecstatic movement beyond individual experience, a movement of consumption by an unattainable((/hl))((/ul))((ul)), impossible ((/ul))((ul))((hl))object of desire((/hl))((/ul)), the hero, as religious ingenu, comes to understand ((ul))the truth of Madame Edwarda's revelation: she is God, but 'GOD figured as a public whore((/ul)) and gone crazy - that, viewed through the optic of "philosophy", makes no sense at all' (p. 233). The non-sense of the un-knowing that manifests itself in poetic intoxication, laughter's expenditure, or ecstasy's flight, also drives eroti­ cism, dissociating it from the impulses of natural animality or sexuality. ((ul))'Eroticism, unlike simple sexual activity is a psychological quest independent of the natural goal((/ul)).,25 ((ul))Located in a psychological or psychoanalytical domain, ((/ul))((ul))((hl))eroticism constitutes one of those experiences in which the fundamental form of the human is brought into question((/hl))((/ul)).¶ For Bataille, it is woman that occupies the place where the object of desire exceeds both objectivity and subjectivity with a glimpse of an unknown infinity. That this is so is no doubt an effect of a particular cultural conjuncture: 'a new representation of woman was emerging at the center of the intellectual epic of the interwar years', Elisabeth Roudinesco argues. This representation, for the surrealists, took the shape of the female crimi­ nal. For psychoanalysis it was the 'female ecstatic' (as represented in Bernini's statue of the Ecstasy ofSaint Teresa), culminating with Madame Edwarda herself, 'a triumphant madwoman, capable of inscribing the name of God on the "rags" hanging from her scarlet sex'.26 Woman, in godless modernity, assumes the intermediary function of a discredited priesthood, the impossible object between finite being and infinity that guarantees sacred excess. Woman's proximity to the divine is manifested in her jouissance.

tag: The notion of debate as a tool to achieve their standards is emblematic of the will to productivity and is exactly what we’re critiquing
cite: Brewer 13 (Ben Brewer is a Graduate Student of Philosophy at Emory University, “Unsaying Non-Knowledge: Georges Bataille and the Mysticism of Writing,” 2013 ///ghs-sc)
text: Though the critiques of project and rationality follow similar structures and are equiprimordial, it is easiest to begin with the critique of utility. ((ul))((hl))According to utility, an object must have((/hl))((/ul))((ul)) reference to ((/ul))((ul))((hl))some external end((/hl))((/ul))((ul)) in order to be considered meaningful((/ul)). In this mode of being-in-the-world, the tool is the primary example of meaning. Importantly, ((ul))((hl))the tool “has no value in itself” and is only meaningful “in relation to an anticipated result”((/hl))((/ul)) (Theory of Religion 28). While the truth of the tool lies in its usefulness towards a given end, the end is itself also grounded in utility. The tools of agriculture, to use Bataille’s example from Theory of Religion, are defined in terms of their usefulness to the cultivation of crops: a plow is only a plow so long as it accomplishes the goal of preparing soil for planting. The resulting food is, in turn, only valuable to the end of being eaten, which is only valuable in terms of its ability to sustain human life, which is only valuable in its ability to do work, etc. The absurdity of this “endless deferral” is matched by the equal absurdity of “a true end, which would serve no purpose” (29). Either utility continues indefinitely such that no individual thing is valuable in itself, or the utility is grounded in something which is not itself useful. ((ul))((hl))A “true end,” must be something with no use-value((/hl))((/ul)) at all. ((ul))This is true for two reasons. The first is((/ul)) clearly explicit in my preceding explanation: ((ul))there must be something at the end of the line((/ul)), so to speak, ((ul))which grounds meaning((/ul)). This is a purely logical objection. ((ul))Meaning based in utility makes impossible the very thing it purports to offer: grounded meaning.((/ul)) ((ul))The second((/ul)) necessity ((ul))deals((/ul)) instead ((ul))with Bataille’s ethical commitment to immanent subjectivity: “What a ‘true end’ reintroduces is the continuous being, lost in the world like water is lost in water”((/ul)) (29). The structure of ((ul))the tool introduces a break into the continuity of animal experiencing. In order for me to use something as a tool, it must first be distinct from me. Once it is distinct from me, I am no longer in an immanent state of continuity with my world. ((/ul))((ul))((hl))The introduction of discontinuity into((/hl))((/ul))((ul)) the indiscriminate immanence of ((/ul))((ul))((hl))existence is the condition of the possibility of a tool. To use a tool((/hl))((/ul))((ul)), therefore, ((/ul))((ul))((hl))is already to be in the realm of project((/hl))((/ul)).3 ((ul))Bataille then introduces the dimension of temporality to the critique of utility in order to critique what he calls “project,”((/ul)) though it could easily be referred to as desire. ((ul))((hl))Project denotes a mode of being-in-the-world in which time itself is experienced as an object to be enlisted in the favor of utility((/hl))((/ul))((ul)). The present becomes meaningful only insofar as its occurrences are useful in relation to the accomplishment of a (future) goal.((/ul)) The critique of this mode of being-in-the-world runs similarly to the critique of utility. ((ul))First of all, ((/ul))((ul))((hl))I will never be fulfilled((/hl))((/ul))((ul)). This is the basic problem of desire or projection: desire is constituted on a lack. I can only desire something I do not have((/ul)). More importantly, it will not actually fulfill my desire; my desire, instead, will simply reconstitute itself with a new object-cause, which will be equally unsatisfactory upon its acquisition. ((ul))((hl))The infinite regress of utility-based meaning manifests itself here as the impossibility of satisfying desire. The((/hl))((/ul))((ul)) ethical ((/ul))((ul))((hl))problem of discontinuity((/hl))((/ul)), however, also ((ul))((hl))reappears with the introduction of temporality((/hl))((/ul)). Right after the above-quoted passage about animality, Bataille also notes that the goshawk eating the hen exists in a way “in which nothing is given in time…in which nothing is given beyond the present” (18). For Bataille, ((ul))((hl))the((/hl))((/ul))((ul)) very ((/ul))((ul))((hl))division of time((/hl))((/ul))((ul)) into past, present, and future ((/ul))((ul))((hl))introduces discontinuity((/hl))((/ul))((ul)) and transcendence ((/ul))((ul))((hl))into the continuous oneness of immanence. This discontinuity is((/hl))((/ul)), for Bataille, ((ul))((hl))the underlying problem of utility((/hl))((/ul))((ul)) ((/ul))as well. ((ul))The idea of ((/ul))((ul))((hl))discontinuity((/hl))((/ul))((ul)), either between subject and object or among past, present, and future, ((/ul))((ul))((hl))is the condition of the possibility of utility’s emergence((/hl))((/ul))((ul)). Nick Land explains, “Bataille’s thought of ((/ul))((ul))((hl))discontinuity((/hl))((/ul))((ul)) is more intricate than his fluent deployment of the word might indicate. It ((/ul))((ul))((hl))is the condition for transcendent illusion((/hl))((/ul))((ul))”((/ul)) (Land 64). ((ul))In this way the same critique of deferral applies to discontinuity: “Discontinuity is not ontologically grounded but positively fabricated”((/ul)) (64). ((ul))The groundlessness of discontinuity is not,((/ul)) then, ((ul))accidental to the groundlessness of deferral, but rather constitutive of it. ((/ul))Finally, ((ul))((hl))Bataille applies the critiques of utility((/hl))((/ul))((ul)) and project ((/ul))((ul))((hl))to the practice of discursive reason((/hl))((/ul)). Broadly speaking, ((ul))discursive reason is the practice of philosophy understood as explanation. Insofar as ((/ul))((ul))((hl))discursive reasoning((/hl))((/ul))((ul)) always occurs within the context of elucidating something for a higher end, usually “truth,” it ((/ul))((ul))((hl))is based in project and utility((/hl))((/ul)). In contradistinction to this approach to philosophy, Bataille poses “sovereign nonknowledge”—a way of philosophizing that does not attempt to elucidate transcendent truths, but rather forces the reader into an experience (“Nonknowledge” 196). ((ul))((hl))Discursive reason also rests on the distinction between subject and object((/hl))((/ul))((ul)). In order to define something for explication or exploration, one must first delimit it from the manifold. I cannot give an account of what a chair is without first designating that a chair is some object distinct from all other possible objects in the world.((/ul)) This ontological problem of discursive reason points to the role that language plays in Bataille’s thought. ((ul))((hl))Language rests on this((/hl))((/ul))((ul)) same ((/ul))((ul))((hl))dividing up of the world((/hl))((/ul))((ul)). It rests on the ability to define a subject as distinct from an object. Even if I proclaim that I am thinking about myself, syntax necessitates that there is an “I” who is thinking (subject) and an “I” which is being thought about (object). This structural necessity is,((/ul)) for Bataille, “((ul))one of the most fateful aberrations of language”((/ul)) (Theory of Religion 28). ((ul))Bataille’s non-knowledge, then, cannot simply be expressed in discursive language. Instead Bataille engages what Michael Sells calls “unsaying,” ((/ul))((ul))((hl))perverting and twisting language against itself in order to “engage the ineffable”((/hl))((/ul)) (Sells 3). In these critiques ((ul))((hl))Bataille attempts to elucidate and undermine the very basis of transcendent subjectivity—discontinuity. The calling into question of the structure of discontinuity, between subject and world, between I and thou, undergirds all of Bataille’s thought.((/hl))((/ul))

text: ((ul))A doctrine of ((/ul))((ul))((hl))salvation has meaning only if we start from the equation 'existence equals suffering.'((/hl))((/ul))((ul)) It is neither a sudden realization nor a series of reasonings which leads us to this equation, but the unconscious elaboration of our every moment, the contribution of all our experiences, minute or crucial((/ul)). tag: God is dead, and we have killed him.
cite: Bataille 38 (Georges Bataille, crazy librarian, “The Obelisk,” in “Visions of Excess: Selected Writings 1927-1939,” translated by Alan Stoekl ///ghs-sc)
text: ((ul))((hl))"Have you not heard,"((/hl))((/ul))((ul)) cried Nietzsche, "((/ul))((ul))((hl))of that madman who((/hl))((/ul))((ul)) lit a lantern in((/ul))((ul)) ((/ul))((ul))the bright morning hours, ran to the marketplace, and ((/ul))((ul))((hl))cried incessantly: "I seek((/hl))((/ul))((ul))((hl)) ((/hl))((/ul))((ul))((hl))God!
